I was given a collection of C. S. Lewis' Christian writings for my Birthday, having wanted to read them for a while. I've been reading Mere Christianity, and finding it by turns, difficult, inspirational, challenging, provoking, interesting, dated and relevant.
 
 What did strike me is the similarity between Lewis' radio broadcasts and the letters of the Apostles in terms of communication with the church as a whole, and with those on the margins looking for instruction. This set me wondering whether it was reasonable that the church accepted a Biblical canon and then declared in to be finished, or whether since that time there have been writers and writings of equal value. There is no division in terms of having met Jesus on earth or not, as St. Paul had not, or in having life changing revelation, as both St. Paul and Lewis. The question, then, comes down to whether the writings are of value and whether the author was inspired by the Holy Spirit.
 
 So, what do others think of C. S. Lewis' work?

From what I understand, the Roman Catholic church (and hence most other churches that share a common heritage with it) titles a number of saints apostles, mainly those responsible for first bringing Christianity to a particular place. St. Augustine, then, is "Apostle to the English", but there are also other New Testament apostles, such as Apollos, Andronicus, Junia and Silas, who are referred to in the Epistles as apostles.
 
 Lewis' own description of his conversion, Surprised by Joy, is a hugely interesting study of his struggle with atheism, and his supreme reluctance to admit the existence of God. For all his later carefully constructed logical argument for God, his own experience was of God pushing His way in and demanding to be heard, his logic and deduction only coming in when it came to deciding whether to believe in Christianity.
